awd_abstract_narration: Virginia Tech proposes to create the CyberCorps(R): Scholarship for Service (SFS) program targeting undergraduate students entering their third year of study and majoring in Computer Engineering and Computer Science. The program provides three years of funding to complete both a B.S. and M.S. through the existing Accelerated Undergraduate/Graduate program, as well as a graduate certificate in Cybersecurity. Scholarships are open to current students at Virginia Tech and students transferring from two-year programs within the Virginia Community College System (VCCS), with whom Virginia Tech has articulation agreements. The program requires a completion of the 18-credit completion graduate certificate in Cybersecurity including network/systems fundamentals, security, cyber law, and electives in cryptography and business aspects of cyber. The project is managed by the Hume Center for National Security and Technology using an apparatus already in place for awarding endowed national security scholarships and fellowships, including a dedicated support for monitoring and mentoring students, and a robust national security career placement program with personal connections to most cyber-related agencies, national labs, and FFRDCs. To fulfill the thesis requirement of the M.S. degree, students conduct research in cybersecurity in one of the six cyber-related labs at the university, including the IT Security Lab designed as a 'teaching hospital' for network security where student research projects can use the production campus network as a testbed for security research. The program provides a major advancement in cyber security education at Virginia Tech by incentivizing study in cybersecurity and by creating a pathway to federal employment. The Hume Center will work with the Center for Enhancement of Engineering Diversity to recruit and retain students from underrepresented populations. Students' graduate research is captured and disseminated through the University Library's VTechWorks. Curriculum and learning environments are available to K-12 and universities accessing the RAVE network nationwide.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the Virginia Tech Scholarship for Service program is to produce the future talent who will perform the job of securely provisioning the nation?s Information Technology System as described in the NICE framework established by NIST. VT educates these students for their roles as security system architects, planners, developers, and researchers by establishing the Virginia Tech CyberScholars Program. The program focus is on students obtaining BS/MS degrees because our goal is to provide engineering and science talent who focus on the NICE Framework major areas of Securely Provision (SP), Analyze (AN), and Investigate (IN). Of course, these advanced degree students will also be involved in other areas of the NICE Framework including Cybersecurity: Forensics, Cyber Operations, Operational Planning, Threat Analysis, Defense Infrastructure Support, Strategic Planning, Security Architect, and System Analysis. The scholarship program targets undergraduate students majoring in Electrical & Computer Engineering and Computer Science who are entering their third year of study. The program provides three years of funding (full tuition, stipend, books, health insurance supplement, and professional development) for the final two years of undergraduate work plus the additional year required to earn an M.S. degree through Virginia Tech?s Accelerated Undergraduate/Graduate Degree program. VT CyberScholars is open to current students at Virginia Tech, as well as students transferring from other universities, or from two-year programs within the Virginia Community College System, with whom Virginia Tech has articulation agreements. Transfer students are generally required to matriculate at least one semester in order to complete perquisites and establish grades normalized to VT norms. CyberScholars will graduate with a Bachelor?s degree in Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, or Computer Science, as well as a Master?s degree in one of these disciplines. Additionally, the students? coursework will focus on cybersecurity and they will earn an undergraduate minor in cybersecurity. CyberScholars gain research experience through their M.S. thesis and the ongoing funded research projects of the degree home department, and government work experience through internships. 
Virginia Tech has had 29 students participate in the program and continues to add new students.
